newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: ASEAN sees Ung Huot's nomination as credible.
newsitem.headline: ASEAN sees Ung Huot's nomination as credible.

text.p: ASEAN views as credible the nomination of Cambodian Foreign Minister Ung Huot for the post of first prime minister of the war-torn country, Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas said on Monday.
Asked whether he regarded the nomination as credible, Alatas told reporters: "It's...a credible form in parliament, certainly."
"There were 97 members of parliament in all, and I think the quorum was only supposed to be 84 to 86," said Alatas, one of ASEAN's three mediators in the Cambodian conflict.
He added, however: "I don't know how it'll be when it comes to confirming (Ung Huot's) election."

Ung Huot was nominated as first prime minister by the Cambodian National Assembly in place of Prince Norodom Ranariddh, ousted in a July 5-6 putsch by coalition colleague and Second Prime Minister Hun Sen.
His nomination came despite an announcement by Ranariddh on Sunday that he had temporarily expelled Ung Huot from his royalist FUNCINPEC party.

Hun Sen, who originally put Ung Huot's name forward to replace Ranariddh, attended the assembly session. Assembly officials, however, said voting for the post could be held only in a week due to administrative delays.
Asked if he had been in touch with Ung Huot, Alatas said: "Yes, on the phone."
Alatas together with the foreign ministers of the Philippines and Thailand make up a team formed by ASEAN to mediate a solution to the Cambodian crisis, sparked by Hun Sen's ouster of Ranariddh.
The crisis kept Cambodia from joining ASEAN on schedule last week and the ministers remain in limbo, awaiting a clear word from Hun Sen on whether he will accept their mission.

Alatas is attending an annual series of meetings of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) together with major Asian and Western powers which have demanded a free and fair election of the new first prime minister as a key to the settlement of the crisis.
They have also endorsed ASEAN's leading role in helping bring peace and stability to the country.
ASEAN comprises Brunei, Burma, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam.
